name: benzo[5,6]phenanthro[3,4-h]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2130

name: benzo[5,6]phenanthro[3,4-h]quinoline
source: Karthikeyan M.; Glen R.C.; Bender A. General melting point prediction based on a diverse compound dataset and artificial neural networks. J. Chem. Inf. Model.; 2005; 45(3); 581-2130
Reason: The base structure for comparison is naphthalene, which has a melting point of 80 degrees Celsius. Benzo[5,6]phenanthro[3,4-h]quinoline contains multiple fused aromatic rings - more specifically, five additional condensed benzene rings attached to the basic naphthalene structure. Each additional ring increases the molecular weight and rigidity of the molecule, which generally leads to an increase in the melting point. If we estimate that each additional benzene ring contributes +38 degrees Celsius to the melting point due to enhanced pi-pi interactions and increased molecular stability, the effect of five additional rings would be roughly 5 x 38 = +190. Therefore, the estimated melting point of benzo[5,6]phenanthro[3,4-h]quinoline would be 80 (for naphthalene) + 190 (for five additional benzene rings) degrees Celsius.
